description:
In this game we find ourselves playing the opponents of the superhero. The title includes up to a maximum of four players, who can however choose from the most iconic villains of Gotham City: Bane, Joker, Catwoman, Mr. Freeze, The Riddler and Harley Quinn.

Each villain will have a Criminal Plan to carry out, developed in different missions (such as taking control of specific territories or making certain results with the dice). Achieving a certain number of objectives will activate the character's special powers, giving the player various advantages during the rest of the game.

While the villains compete for the districts of Gotham City (following the traditional RisiKo dice-rolling mechanic!), our hero is not standing idle. When five 1's are rolled during a turn, Batman goes into action, clearing one or more territories on the board and wreaking havoc in the fight for control of the metropolis. Especially in the initial stages it will not be easy to watch, but it will always be a great emotion to swoop into our opponents. It will be less pleasant when it's our turn to face the Dark Knight, but that's part of the challenge too.

In addition to conquering all of Gotham, you can take home the game by completing one of three objectives, common to all participants. However, every time a criminal empire is definitively defeated, the player who accomplished the feat can choose to eliminate one of the conditions.

Will you be able to mine the most from asteroids without dying?

Be careful, 3 active mines and the asteroid field explodes, along with your profits!

Avoid pirate ships that paralyze your probes.

Objective:

Your goal is to play all the cards from your deck, and make the best score.

To do so, you play each card from your deck with the following rules:

     the card can never cover a previously played card
     the card must be placed adjacent (horizontally, vertically or diagonally) to the previously played card.


You lose the game if there are no legal moves and at least a card is not played, of if there are 3 active Mines at the same time in the playfield.

You win the game if you managed to put all cards from the deck in the play field.

Includes solo, 2 player competitive & 2 player cooperative modes.

This is the family edition from "Don't Panic".
There are category cards as in the base game, but each has 3 categories with one of the levels hard, medium and simple.
At the beginning of the game a level is set for each player, easy for children, hard for adults with many knowledge.
It's also a timed game, but each round the active player gets only 1 category and has to name 5 words, which match this category. The timer is stopped and the remaining number are the points he gets for this round.
3 times each player is allowed to ask for a new category (3 chips are available for each player to mark this)
After 5 rounds the player with the highest number of points wins.

—user summary

In this game you have to collect 3 bird cards.
16 bird cards, 16 square memory cards (attributes)
Each bird has one of two possibilities of the 4 attributes: eyes, feathers on the head, beak, claws.
The activ player turns a bird card from the bird card deck.
Now he turns 1 memory card after each other, as long as he finds a matching attribute to the bird card.
If he finds all 4, he wins the bird card. If he turns a wrong attribute or a right the second time, his turn is over.
In bioth cases all memory cards are turned on the backside.
Who wins the third bird card wins the game.

—user summary

In Fox Kids each player gets a board with 8 different cartoon character on them. You can also find these characters on a pile of circle shaped tiles that are in the middle of the table. Each player blindly chooses 5 tiles and try to see if they match any of the characters you have on your board. If so you can keep them, if not you return them face up, so everyone can see which characters is on that tile. Luckily there are a few wild cards among the pile which you can use to fill in a missing character on your board.

If you want to try to make it a bit harder, you can play level 2. You flip over your board and instead of the preprinted characters you get 8 empty circles on your board. On the added notepad every player picks for themselves 8 different characters they try to collect. In this way you can't really know what characters your opponents try to find. Whoever get's all of their characters first wins the game.

—user summary

A strategic dice game. Based upon King of Dice this board game consists of two board game pieces with 15 territory spaces. Players compete for cards by rolling and rerolling dice. These cards allow the players to place castle tiles and gain gemstones and dragon fires on the game boards.
When enough castles are placed the game ends and the players gain points for their biggest territory, their gemstones and the most dragon fires. The player with the most points wins.

Each summer you spend your vacation with cousins in the mansion of grandpa, Hector Simon, the greatest adventurer in the world! This evening, he is absent and all his enemies will take the opportunity to take revenge. But they didn't count on you!
Search the mansion, create traps and save as many treasures as possible from the clutches of the Jealous!

Setup : choose a character and draw a random personality.
Phase 1 : the Jealous come inside, draw the first Clock card, it indicates the the number of Jealous to enter the mansion.
Phase 2 : Search the manor, every player draw Object cards.
Phase 3 : Assemble your objects to create traps.
Phase 4 : Reduce the resistance of the jealous by triggering your traps to save treasures.
				
				
					For each trap, you need to explain its operating mechanism out loud! Make way for the imagination and the pain!Phase 5 : All the Jealous still in the mansion will be able to steal Treasures cards.

The game ends when one full turn of the clock has been completed.

The game also ends immediately when 10 treasures have been stolen by the Jealous. You have all lost then and Grandpa will be very disappointed.

Childrens version of activity based on the "Die Oktonauten" TV series from Toggolino (SuperRTL, Toggo plus).
It's a under water submarine race. There are characters and things known from the series. These are described by one player with pantomime, drawing or description. Only the players who finds the right answer can move forward.
It can be played in 2 teams or cooperative.

—user summary

Hidden somewhere along the tropical coastline, you'll find a charming little beach town called Twin Palms. Here you'll see dolphins jumping, lovers holding hands, and children playing in the sand...always in pairs.

Twin Palms is a beach-themed escape from your traditional trick-taking card game. At the start of each of the game's 5-8 rounds, you bid the number of tricks (0-5) you think you'll claim with the ten cards in your hand. Wait, ten cards = five tricks? Yes, because each time you play to a trick, you play two cards at once!

You play the game with 1-3 suits of cards depending on your desired level of difficulty and the number of players at the table; each suit has cards numbered 0-10 and a wild, with each card appearing twice. The strongest play is a pair of cards that are the same number, with high numbers beating low ones, and with palm trees beating dolphins, which beat sunglasses, which beat pairs that are of different suits. If no one plays a pair, then whoever played the highest single card wins the trick. After five tricks, you score points if you've met your bid exactly. (If you bid a non-zero number of tricks but missed, you still score 1 point per trick taken.)

What's more, if you want to play risky, you can place bets on your bids, giving you an additional way to win (or lose) points. Whoever has the most points after the designated number of rounds wins!

FIND, CONNECT, GUESS!

Find the Items.
Connect the items on your board.
Guess what you are drawing!
Connect items on your board according to the Challenge card and give shape to an object. To win, be the first to guess what you are drawing. With its fast-paced and seamless gameplay, Connecto is wonderfully addictive!

Connecto is based on the concept of connect-the-dots: connect the dots and guess what you are drawing. In each round, a card with several items is revealed.

Simultaneously, players connect these items on their board to draw a design. The first player who guesses what they are drawing (even if the picture is incomplete) writes it down on their board and starts the countdown for the other players. Once the time is up, players win points if they guessed right.

During each game, you will have to connect and guess 8 images from among 184 challenges with various difficulties. Learn gradually how to play with our 3 progressive tutorials that lead you through challenges of increasing complexity.

Contents include:

5 Player boards
96 Large format cards
5 Dry-erase markers
1 Sand-timer
Instructions
 Designed for:

Up to 10 players
Ages 8 and up
An average play time of 30 minutes per game

Thirty years after sending the first colonial ships from Ganymede, humanity decided to launch Project Galileo! Its goal: Settle the four main satellites of Jupiter (Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto) in order to broaden human presence in the solar system. This project is named after the Italian intellectual Galileo, the first to observe these four satellites in the sky in 1610.

In Galileo Project, you play as the same corporations involved in the events of Ganymede and settle the four satellites of Jupiter by acquiring robots from Earth and Mars, recruiting experts, developing technologies, and building superstructures.

Galileo Project is a standalone game in the Ganymede universe, combining combos and engine-building.

— description from the publisher (translated).

Quest: Volume I is a game with 2,520 general knowledge questions: World, Arts and Entertainment, Society, Science and Technology, Sport and Leisure and Variety. Before answering each question, the player must bet the amount of points he wants to walk on the board if he gets the answer right. Players can even choose the topics they know best to answer. But it's good to know all the subjects, as in the end you'll have to answer a question on the topic chosen by the other players. Are you up for this challenge?

My Bot Bytes is a fun and fast-paced action programming game that will have the entire family coding without them realizing it! Teaches kids (and adults) some basics of coding!

You are interns trying to impress the Scientist to be the chosen one! Control two Bots to collect spare parts hidden around a Robotics lab. Bots can be coded to move using Navigation control cards but watch out! - the Scientist's Navigation System only gives limited navigation cards. Use logic loops to build logic into the Bots to move around obstacles (which include the Scientist's pets!). Be the first to navigate your Bot to collect all spare parts and complete your assembly board to win!

Game setup randomized so that no two games are alike!

Simple wargame following Alexander the Great's conquest of the Persian Empire and India.

Each player has two armies, led by Alexander and Antipater on one side, Darius and Memnon on the other side. Each army has a strenght track and is represented by a single counter on the map. Combat is resolved rolling a die per player, with various modifiers.

Alexander must conquer most of the Persian Empire and India before turn 14 to gain a decisive victory. A minor victory can be achieved by conquering Egypt instead.

--user summary

Published on "Guerre e Guerrieri" magazine, issue #37.

To play House of Cronies, each player’s Cabinet consists of up to 6 cronies; each carrying a set number of votes, plus an optional foreign ally. All cronies, besides the foreign allies, can be elected as president or vice-president. Other positions such as Finance, Justice, Service Delivery and Communications, can only be filled by specialists.

Two decks of cards are placed on the table: the main deck and the tactics deck. The main deck consists of influence, corruption and crony cards and the tactics deck contains only tactics cards. Players start with seven cards from the main deck and two tactic cards each. Any cronies or foreign ally in the initial hand must be placed in the cabinet immediately (and any crony or ally that can not be placed is discarded).

In each round of House of Cronies, five cards are drawn from the main deck and placed face up in the middle of the table. In turn order, players can either pick up an influence / corruption card OR bid influence, corruption or a combination of both for a crony. Players can only gain one card per round, so any player who outbids another forfeits their turn. Players that are outbid, get their turn and their influence / corruption bid card back.

The end of the game occurs when there are no cards left in the deck or fewer cards than needed to draw for a new round. A final round is played for players to buy and used tactics before the election takes place and the player with the most votes wins!

Schermstrijd is a family game. Children battle against their parents to gain more screentime! It's a simple card game in which you try to duplicate the colored wifi-code laid out in the center of the table. Sabotage your opponents and be the first to complete your code to win the game!

The game is played in 3 to 5 rounds (you can choose). Set a starting time and roll the dice to see how much screentime can be added or extracted. 
4 colored wifi-card are layed out in the center in the beginning of the round. The first player to duplicate the code wins the round.

During a turn you roll a dice to see what actions you may perform. This can vary from stealing a card to changing the code in the center. You play cards to complete your code or to prevent your opponents to complete theirs.

Schermstrijd the battle is a fun and easy family game to end discussions about, well... screentime. In only 30 minutes of offline fun it is settled. Do you dare to battle?

—description from the publisher

"The Different Game"

The game is promoted as "fast moving, surprising - different". It is played by four players on a 13x13 multi-coloured checkered board. On each side of the board, there is a role (producer, doctor, politician, and opportunist). One of these roles is assumed by each of the four players. Playing time is presented as being one to two hours. The board also states that the game is "a game of skill", played with "no dice or cards".

MAKALOT was published by Modern Games Company in Oaktown, Indiana. The copyright date is 1937, held by Roy A. Beard. A "patent pending" notation is shown on the game board.

In Bossa (åŠèŒ¶) (ã¼ã£ã•), two players compete to play each of the tiles from their hand.  The tiles show the traditional dice faces, 1 through 6, in various combinations of white and black pips.  If a tile shows 5 pips, but 2 are white and 3 are black, it is treated as a 2 white or a 3 black, but it will never be used as a 5.

At the start of the game, the players roll two dice, one with black pips and one with white pips.  The players extend a virtual row, in both directions, from these dice.  For instance, if the black pipped dice is a 6, the players are looking to play tile(s) of value 5 to one side, and 7 to the other.

In addition to drawing and playing tile(s) each turn, the players have a few special abilities that can be triggered once per game.

The first person to play all of the tiles from their hand wins.
user summary

The publisher says:
A simple yet stylish game of tactics, strategy and a little luck for 2 players. Following either the dice with white pips or black pips, place the tile with the same colored dots alongside the dice.

Utilizing the three action cards offensively, defensively or to turn the tables, use up all the tiles in your hand before your opponent to win!

Using both the tiles in your hand and the pile, read the play, exploit the action cards, and with the luck of the draw, seize victory!

There are two types of rules: the Basic Rules, which are easy to play with, and the Advanced Rules, which are more thoughtful and fun to play with.

How will you build your Victory?

Slash & Spells is a  Hero Building Battleground. Embody your Legendary Hero and unlock your unique ability tokens using magical Relics across the realm. Command clever card play and take ever-evolving heroic actions.

Slash & Spells is an epic duel using action selection, variable player powers, and hero tech trees tied into your relic choices. Players control unique Heroes drawn into an epic battle during your turn you take 6 basic actions to grow in power, attack, move, play cards from your unique hero deck, and ultimately knock down your enemies by reducing their health to zero.

The battle takes place via attack actions and playing cards from your hand. Each card that resolves deals their base Dmg and card effects to their target. Once a card has been played its card effect becomes an available action for your hero to take.

Victory is yours when you claim the most Knockdowns by the end of rounds and can claim your true destiny!

-description from designer

Stampede is a set-collection auction game themed around stamp collecting.

On a player's turn, they reveal 1 to 4 cards from a prepared deck to auction.  The players then choose how many dice to roll.  The player who rolls the highest amount is the winner, but will pay the value of the second highest amount rolled.  The players pay their bids in dice, with each 6 coins (pips) they need to pay consuming 1 of their dice.

The end of the game is triggered once a certain card is revealed near the bottom of the deck.  The player with the most points from the cards they've collected wins.

The world is new, and fledgling civilizations beseech you for aid. In this 2-4 player game, you will assume the role of a Greek God vying for control of the world and the future of your civilization. Wield divine power using asymmetric abilities and your customizable action deck. There are 13 Gods to choose from, providing a different challenge and experience each time you play.

As a God you exercise your will, represented by various cards and abilities, to build the world as you play. On your turn you will play cards and pay for their scalable effects by exhausting your civilization’s cities and temples.  New cities and temples can be built when your population grows, making your action cards more powerful and your turns more efficient.  You’ll be able to shape the shared world map as players choose which unique hex-shaped land tiles to add, giving the mortals new areas to grow into.  Each land has its own mix of geographic type, attack and defense bonus, population growth rate, potential build sites, movement cost, and location abilities.  No two worlds will look the same.   You will also guide your Hero and High Priestess to go on quests, use location abilities on land tiles, lead your people to new areas, or convert the non-believers. There are also 12 powerful mythological creatures that can be summoned, each with their own abilities to enhance your strategy.

As powerful as you are, the mortals are not entirely within your control as they have their own free will.  They will pray for various signs, protections, or resources, and answering these prayers will grant you a range of benefits in return.  In addition, at the end of each player's turn the population will move and grow in response to the Mortal die's result.

The game ends after 3 Ages of raising mountains, answering prayers, causing catastrophes, unlocking technologies, warring, and building cities, temples, and monuments. Victory points are awarded for area control of the world, your completed quests and world-building secret objectives, technological discoveries, military victories, Follower's morale, and other achievements. Each God also has their own way to earn VP.  The god with the most VP takes their rightful seat on Mount Olympus.

—description from the publisher

On a map of Europe, you build track to fulfill your contracts.
On his turn, each of the players chooses one of 6 action phases and triggers it. All players act while the triggering player has an advantage (like in Puerto Rico). In the contract phase, you choose contracts that include a start city, a destination city and sometimes 1 or 2 in between. It says which type of locomotive you are allowed to use and which and how many wagons.

In the building phase, you connect any 2 cities by paying for the track you build. In the market phase you buy locomotives and wagons, in the auction phase you must offer at least one locomotive or wagon that is not yet part of a contract. In the reward phase, you get money for your connected cities and in the state subsidy phase you  receive a locomotive or wagon for free. At the end of a round all players receive income according to their partly or completely fulfilled contracts.

After a player has an agreed amount of fulfilled contracts, the game ends and you get points for fulfilled contracts, income and connected cities and minus points for contracts not at least partly fulfilled.

—user summary

ãƒªã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ»ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ»ãƒ¬ãƒ‡ã‚£ (LIQUOR for LADY) is a 2 player card game from Japan. The theme has the players trying to buy the right cocktail for woman at a nightclub. Each player chooses a card in secret and reveals it simultaneously. If the difference between the values on the cards is more than 3, then the lower card wins (the lady liked the drink offered).

The player that favours the most woman at the bar is the winner.
user summary

Coralon is the base trick-taking game for Crab Fragment Labs' Vines deck.  The Vines deck has eleven cards in five suits, including Ace (high) and four face cards: Knight, Bishop, Farmer, and Tar. Below these are the ranks 7 through 2. Games with the Vines deck include several trick-taking games for 3 to 6 players, including cutthroat and team games, based on familiar mechanics from games like Hearts, Pitch, and Euchre, with an abundant assortment of clever innovations.

Players bid on the number of tricks they will win, with the highest bidder leading and choosing trump.

If you make your bid, you score the number of tricks won and your opponents score nothing.

If you make over your bid you and your opponents all score the number of tricks won.

If you make under your bid you score nothing and your opponents score the number of tricks won.

Game ends when one player reaches a winning score (dependent on number of players).

Deck 52: Space Wrecked is a quick solo dungeon crawl card game, where the player fights through randomly generated levels of a derelict spaceship, trying to survive, and reach the escape shuttle.


    The game can be played as a single scenario (5-10 min, you win by finding the level exit) or a campaign (a sequence of missions).
    Campaign mode (10-20 missions, increasing difficulty, character upgrades).
    Each game level is randomly unfolding while you're exploring it. 
    Combinations of 7 random Objectives (win conditions) and 7 Threats (gameplay modifiers) add more replayability.


—description from the designer

A very rare, limited release board game bundled and sold with candy by Bandai.

The players spin the wheel to figure out how much to move (1-3 spaces). Then, they move their token and defeat monsters (also by spinning the wheel) to collect weapon tokens.

Once someone has four weapon tokens, the game turns into the dungeon phase, wherein players race to get to the boss and defeat it, acquiring a triforce fragment. Then the game goes back to the overworld and the process is repeated.

Whoever has the most triforce pieces by the end of the fourth dungeon wins.

Help climber Sam reach the yeti at the top of the mountain in this cooperative vocabulary game.

Sam needs your speed and your vocabulary to overcome obstacles and reach the top of the mountain. Roll the dice, find out on a map the challenge you will have to meet and each time you succeed, Sam can move a little further towards his goal.

Players pick a challenge card off the draw stack and roll a die to see how many words they must recite to meet the challenge.  If no one can pick a correct word, they must roll the die and move back that many spaces.

Who wins? Whichever team or player first gets Sam to the top of the mountain.


Un jeu de vocabulaire coopératif
Aidez l’alpiniste Sam à rejoindre le yéti au sommet de la montagne!Amateurs de jeu de mots, voilà votre chance de briller aussi en alpinisme avec Sam, qui a besoin de votre rapidité et de votre vocabulaire pour franchir les obstacles et atteindre le sommet de la montagne. Lancez le dé, découvrez sur une carte le défi que vous aurez à relever et chaque fois que vous réussissez, Sam peut avancer un peu plus vers son but.

Qui l’emporte? L’équipe ou le joueur qui, le premier, permettra à Sam d’atteindre le sommet de la montagne.

In this cannabis-themed party game for adults, each player has to take a card and pass the indicated test. A test is like a challenge, for example, "guess a movie by doing mimic". If you pass the challenge correctly, you earn victory points.

Game ends when there are no more cards. The player with most victory points wins.

Think green and play responsibly. No plants have been harmed during the creation of this game.

ESTE JUEGO DE MESA  NO PRETENDE FOMENTAR EL CONSUMO DE SUSTANCIAS NOCIVAS PARA LA SALUD, SIMPLEMENTE OFRECE UNA ALTERNATIVA DE OCIO CREATIVO PARA CONSUMIDORES HABITUALES.

4.20 Game está pensado para amparar la igualdad entre hombres y mujeres, utilizando un lenguaje inclusivo y visibilizando de manera igualitaria la figura del hombre y de la mujer. Para ello las dos mascotas del juego son: “CLARITA LA SEMILLITA Y ANTOÑÍN EL COGOLLÍN”.

Por otra parte en las pruebas que hay que superar se ha considerado la posible diversidad física que pueda presentar cualquier participante. Se trata de un juego inclusivo en el que cualquier persona con movilidad reducida puede participar.

Para finalizar esta presentación es necesario mencionar que durante la creación de este juego no ha sufrido daño alguno ningún vegetal.

¡Yo No Tomo! (I do not drink!) is a hilarious card game that appeals to competitiveness and is designed for meetings with friends where drinks and the desire to have a good time are present.

The game challenges each team to get all the cards in their BAR before another does or before they have had enough to give up. In the attempt, each team must defend themselves with the cards they have in their possession to avoid getting drunk, while at the same time they can attack their opponents with cards that make them drink. This game is designed and optimized to be played in teams, but its optional individual version also works very well and is just as fun.

¡Yo No Tomo! is just as fun and competitive without alcohol, and for this it is recommended to draw the TRAGO cards.

The 5 zoo area cards are laid out, the animal cards are added, all other cards are stacked face down, each player has 7 cards. Whoever's turn it is rolls the dice and moves the game piece, then he can lay or discard cards and draw new ones. Whoever completes a row with food, baby animals, scales with the animal keeper or regardless of cards laid with the veterinarian takes the row for victory points. When all the animals in an area are cleared, the player who has collected the most cards wins.

Players use their characters and schemes to secure their claim to the throne. After 6 rounds of play, the player whose family has accumulated the most Influence points wins the game.

The emergence of a neighbouring kingdom destabilizes the great families of the realm and forces them to reconsider their feuds in favour of more political alliances. Yet under the mask of cooperation, ambition still burns and violence will resurface at the first betrayal…

A third stand-alone episode to beautifully conclude the Oriflamme saga. The game introduces 10 innovative effects offering subtle tactical options and rich political decisions.  This opus invites to understand the dynamics around the table and to seek a balance between aggression and negotiation! The Empress will reward you but will grant a favour to a rival. The Diplomat will give you the opportunity to forge an alliance with other players. Yet violence is still ready resurface at any moment: the Insurrection will eliminate the two adjacent cards provided you discard a point accumulated on it!

Oriflamme: Alliance offers 10 new action cards that can be mixed with Oriflamme and/or Oriflamme: Ablaze or be used as a standalone.

Contains:

    50 Influence cards (10 in 5 different colors)
    5 player help cards
    63 Influence point tokens (value 1 and 5)
    5 Accusation tokens
    1 First Player tile
    1 Resolution Direction tile
An old suspense and horror game for kids and adults.

A collection of 2 family games:

Grand Pursang

Spectacular horse race with a minimum of 3 players and a maximum of 6. Before starting, the participants will decide how many races they will run per game. Each one receives an initial sum of money, with their objective being to obtain the highest capital at the end of the game. Each player, once received and studied his cards, bets on the horse that he considers can win, this choice is secret and is kept in reserve until the end of the race. Then, according to his card playing skills, his audacity and his luck with the dice, he will try to get his favorite horse to cross the finish line in 1st or 2nd place.

Zodíaco

Original, easy and exciting betting game where, starting from an initial sum that each player receives at the beginning of the game, the objective of each one is to conquer the greatest fortune. From 2 to 6 players participate and it is played without a time limit since only the luck of each one will determine the permanence of it. Let's try Zodiac and good luck!

Your goal in Florist is to create bouquets of three flowers as whoever first creates five bouquets wins.

To set up, shuffle the twenty flower cards, deal four to each player, then lay out the remaining twelve cards in a row. Each player places their florist card next to one of the six cards in the middle of the row, then the game begins.

On a turn, play a card from your hand to move your florist in the market, then pick up the card adjacent to where you moved and leave the played card in its place. If you now have a bouquet in hand — three cards of the same value or type or three cards in a straight — score a bouquet by revealing one flower on your scoring card, then replace the three cards in the bouquet with the three cards at one end of the flower market.

If your florist lands on the same space as the opponent in the market, reveal all cards in your hand to see who has the higher value and wins a point — except that you don't count cards that match the revealed symbols on your opponent's scoring card.

Sherwood is an introductory Tactical level wargame providing simplified rules that are based on the highly successful Cry Havoc series. The game has two levels of rules: one intended for young players (10 years and up) and those new to wargaming; a second level introduces additional rules that provide a more realistic gameplay. Finally, experienced players will be able to play with the complete rules of the Norman Saga series.
This wargame allows players to immerse themselves in the adventures of the famous Robin Hood and his band of outlaws. They will face the terrible Sheriff of Nottingham and his men in multiple skirmishes in Sherwood Forest or in the nearby village inn.

Rules are intended to simulate man-to-man combat, missile fire with bows, crossbows, or javelins. It's possible to ambush your opponent by pouncing from trees.

The counter sheet provides close to 60 different characters in various stances: Healthy, stunned, wounded or... dead!

Box contents:
> (4) 11" x 16" (or 28 x 40 cm) full-color tactical maps
> (1) 8" x 12" (or 21 x 29.7 cm) counter sheet printed in full color
> (1) 24-page booklet including the rules; the historical background and 8 scenarios
> (1) play sheet for handy reference
> (1) 10-sided die
> (1) counter tray

Game scales:
> 1 counter = 1 character
> 1 turn = 2 seconds
> 1 map hex = +/- 2m (6 feet)

—description from the designer

Elephant in the Room  is a fast paced party game for 4 to 8 players.

Each round two players take on the role of speakers and draw a card from the deck. They must have have a conversation about the secret topic on the card while the other players listen in and attempt to guess the key words!

The other players try to guess the topic and if they get it right and they score the card and are the speaker next round! Guess wrong and they have to wait for another player to make a guess before they can try again!

Score enough elephants on your cards to win the game!

—description from the designer

A cataclysm wiped out part of the global population and compelled all survivors to live hidden due to the harsh weather.

You are one of them and you heard some rumors about a dome build somewhere in the East. A place where you'll be able to start all over again and try to plant the seed for a new society.

Dome is a surviving deckbuilding game for 1 to 4 players in which every action you'll take will be critical. Your journey to Dome will be tough, whereas you'll try to find food, parrain new members for your crew or barter items for your survival.

Each player starts with the same deck. At your turn, you will play ALL your hand : 

     "Exploration" to reach Dome or send explorer to quest,
     "Food" to cook skewered frogs, 
     "People" to use their special skill if you feed them, otherwise they will starve to death...
     "Hope" to convince people to join your team or barter items.


When a player reach Dome or when three piles of cards are empty, the last turn occurs. The player with the most Influence Points on all the cards they acquired during the game wins.

—description from the designer
Hex and counter wargame covering the battle for a single farmstead on the field of Waterloo.
Hex and counter wargame covering part of the action on the second day of the Battle of Gettysburg.

Have you ever said...

...that would be a GREAT name for a band?  Have you ever put two words together from two shops next to each other to make a hilarious name or phrase?  Well, Name The Thing might be the next party game for you to try!

Take turns reading prompts, judging names, and thinking up names to vie for the best names for things!  Can you be the wittiest of your friends and name all the things?

—description from the publisher

Paperbag Dungeon is a tile-laying dungeon builder, with elements of "tower defense," hidden puzzles, and resource management.

Each turn you will choose a card to add to your dungeon. Build carefully because one wrong tunnel could let in monsters that have the ability to dig through walls, open doors and crash your Dungeon Gate.

Mechanincs include: Tower Defence with randomized monsters, flip cards to upgrade defenses and mine gems,map building, hidden pictures, and logic puzzles.

Hey all, Scott here! Evade taxes like never before with the Scott The Woz edition of the classic board game MONOPOLY! Buy, sell and trade iconic locations from the series such as The Shaft Family Estate, The Litigation Station, and Stale Pretzels while using custom tokens of items on Scott’s desk! “Liquidate the company” and go for broke in MONOPOLY: Scott The Woz Edition!

The player pieces are a "The Internet and You" Tape, '08 Stack, Old Phone, Nostalgia Goggles, Party Hat, and a Tambourine.

Limited to 5000 units.

From the rules:
Introduction
This is a reworking of a two-player Euchre variant that I was taught about 35 years ago in Arnprior, Ontario (a small town near Ottawa). It appears to have been a local variation on Six Hand Almonte Euchre (which seems a reasonable conclusion considering Almonte and Arnprior are roughly 30km apart).

Object
Seventeen tricks are played each hand; the object is to win at least nine of them.
The Cards
A pack of 39 cards is used consisting of A K Q J 10 9 8 7 6 in four suits (hearts, diamonds, clubs and spades) plus three distinct jokers (called Bennies).

Nostalgix is the culmination of decades of trading card game experience from industry veterans. By blending our favorite mechanics from the long history of classic card games and introducing several more unique to Nostalgix we have created a game that feels familiar yet fresh.

In our debut Base Set, a worldwide event has trapped anyone who falls asleep in a shared lucid world populated by characters from fictional universes humans have invented over the years. Join Heroes like Vix of the Six and Doctor Corvus and clash Fighters like the powerful Booster Box Dragon, Avengaline, and Gametron against each other to reclaim 10 portal counters, return these characters to their rightful homes and restore the multiverse!

D-Spirits is a fast paced Trading Card Game. It is designed to mitigate the luck you find in TCGs. The game feature 2 deck, allowing you to draw the type of card you really need at any given moment during the game.

Each of the 160 original spirits have game-bending effects that make each game different.

Taking inspiration from other "monster catcher" card games, players (or "D-Tectives" as they are called) take turn summoning "D-Spirits" to playing field. The D-Spirits can then attack on another or their opponent, to inflict damage.

Uniquely, each D-Spirit, has an SP value & when a player's D-Spirit is defeated, that player loses that much SP. 
Each player starts with 5000 SP & the goal is to reduce your opponent's SP to 0.

DIEX AÏE 2 ("God helps" in Latin, the war cry of the Duke of Normandy - Pronounce "Dooss Ah-yeah") is set in England just before the battle of Hastings in the second half of the 11th Century. It depicts the numerous fights that Saxons fought initially against invaders from Scandinavia and the Continent to resist the "Norman Yoke". DIEX AÏE 2 includes a campaign game: It is used to generate tactical scenarios which are played on the standard maps of the series.
DIEX AÏE 2 is a companion game to the popular GUISCARD 2 game. Like this one, DIEX AÏE is a complete boxed game with counters, maps, rules, scenarios and play sheets.

This new version includes all the materials of the original game, but with counters printed on much thicker boards, new additional counters and map. New scenarios featuring the Danes are also provided.

—description from the designer

Mail your True Love one Christmas card each day—and be sure to boast to everyone else about it. In order to keep up with all the other suitors, you might have to lie about what you’ve sent. But lying is half the fun! Will you win by being the sneakiest liar, or by catching others in THEIR lies?

Bah! Humbug! is a bluffing and deduction card game that uses a special card deck based on the traditional "Twelve Days of Christmas" carol (12 x Drummers Drumming, 11 x Pipers Piping, etc.) plus a deck of 12 cards that form a circular wreath or calendar in the center of the table.

Each round, players are dealt a hand of Christmas cards. They then take turns secretly mailing 1  Christmas card to their True Love (playing a card face-down on the calendar). These cards are played in descending order, from 12 to 1. As each player boasts about what card they've sent, other players may shout, “Bah! Humbug!” to catch them in a lie. Lies that go unchallenged are awarded "coal" at the end of the round, while lies that are successfully caught earn the accuser 1 "holly berry" (or take away holly berries, if the accuser is wrong.)

A player can win Bah! Humbug! in either of two ways: by being the most successful liar (collecting the most coal tokens), or by being the best at catching other liars (collecting the most holly berries).

The cover of FYFE shows a dreamy South Seas location with a blue sea, beach, and palm trees — but what will you find as you dig in the sand, and can you arrange your discoveries in ideal scoring combinations?

Each player has their own 5x5 grid, 7 lucky charm tiles, and 15 scoring boards. The game includes 125 tokens, with each token showing one of five colors, one of five symbols, and one of five numbers (1-5). The scoring boards show conditions that you must meet in order to earn the points listed on that board, e.g., the numbers 1-5 in sequence, tokens of the same color, tokens with different symbols, three tokens of one color and two tokens of another color, etc.

To start the game, draw two tokens from the bag and place them at the bottom of your playing board. Place one of these tokens in an empty space of your grid, then choose a scoring board and place it in the row, column, or (if appropriate) diagonal line in which that token was placed. On each subsequent turn, draw one token, place it on your game board, then choose one of your two tokens to place. If this newly placed token doesn't have a scoring board pointing at it, choose one of your unplaced scoring boards and place it in the row, column, or diagonal.

As soon as a line is filled with five tokens, if you have met the conditions on the scoring board for this line, flip it over to the side that shows points; if you are the first and only player to complete this scoring board this round, take the associated 3-point bonus tile. If you complete and score multiple lines on the same turn, take 5-20 bonus points depending on whether you scored two, three, or even four lines at once.

If someone drew a lucky charm token at the start of the round, they draw a replacement token, then all players can choose to use and discard one of their lucky charm tiles. These tiles allow you to exchange the tokens in your reserve, place a token on the board as a joker, swap an already fulfilled scoring board for another one, and so on. Each unused lucky charm tile is worth points at game's end. After 25 rounds, players tally their points for scoring boards, first tiles, lucky charm tiles, and bonuses to see who has the highest score.

Ricochons is a cooperative game.

In each box there are 30 grids filled with words. For each grid, the goal is to complete a dialog by solving riddles through associating words and ideas in the right sequence. The words that remain left at the end of the grid will form a rebus that will help the players to complete an existing dialog.

Each grid can be solved separately, but the dialog to be completed continues from one grid to another and tells a story of funny detectives investigation (this is the theme).

All players work together in associating the words and solving the riddles. There is no restriction in communication and the game finishes when a grid is solved.

Gustav Germ, the famous gourmet critic, is whirling through the city and is once again distributing his coveted gourmet stars. He also visits the restaurant “Oily Oyster” – your chance to put your culinary skills to the test! 
But there is a problem: To prepare delicious dishes, there are only three cooking pots available that you have to share with the competition. ... and there’s that annoying pot lid that’s always in the way and prevents you from completing a recipe. Anyone who, despite all the hurdles, prepares their dishes reasonably correctly and receives the most gourmet stars will be personally awarded the golden toque by Gustav Germ.

On your turn, take 1 out of 3 actions. 
You can either 

     Draw 2 new ingredients, or
     Draw 2 new recipes, or
     Place 1 or 2 ingredients into a pot + move the pot lid!


Pots are placed in the middle of the table and are available for everyone. As soon as one pot is filled with ingredients (amount = 6), everyone has the chance to show one of their recipes and collect points. The more matching ingredients someone has, the more points they get.
Always keep an eye on the displayed menu! You can get even more points if you show the right type of recipe at the right moment.

The game ends after someone has served 6 meals. The player with the most points wins the game!
